name: Pink, Pose, punk, Pilgrim
description: Alice Babidge's costume design for True History of the Kelly Gang sees the iconic foursome and their accomplices in dresses, a gender-expansive stance that connects to other rebellious outlooks on the world.

key_work.title: Costume dresses from the True History of the Kelly Gang
key_work.brief_description: Crafted from used vintage fabrics and sourced from markets, the individualised dresses in True History of the Kelly Gang are likened to warpaint to scare the enemy by the film’s characters, but they also speak to their inner selves.

constellations_primary.name: Pink, Pose, punk, Pilgrim

start.title: Scott Pilgrim vs. the World
start.creator_credit: Edgar Wright, Eric Gitter, Marc Platt, Nira Park, Keith Acheson and Richard Bain
start.headline_credit: Canada, Japan, United Kingdom and United States of America, 2010

video_links.name: Scott Pilgrim Vs. The World - Official Trailer
Scott Pilgrim vs. the World - International Trailer

start.brief_description: As bass guitarist for a garage-rock band, Scott Pilgrim has never had trouble getting a girlfriend; usually, the problem is getting rid of them. But when Ramona Flowers skates into his heart, he finds she has the most troublesome baggage of all: an army of ex-boyfriends who will stop at nothing to eliminate him from her list of suitors.

constellations_other.name: Pink, Pose, punk, Pilgrim
constellations_other.description: Alice Babidge's costume design for True History of the Kelly Gang sees the iconic foursome and their accomplices in dresses, a gender-expansive stance that connects to other rebellious outlooks on the world.

end.title: Street Fighter II
end.brief_description:
A sequel to Street Fighter, Street Fighter II improved upon the many concepts introduced in the first game, including the use of command-based special moves and a six-button configuration, while offering players a selection of multiple playable characters, each with their own unique fighting style and special moves.

Street Fighter II is credited for starting the fighting game boom during the 1990s. Its success led to the production of several updated versions, each offering additional features and characters over previous versions, as well as many home versions. Some of the home versions of the Street Fighter II games have sold millions of copies, with the SNES port of the first Street Fighter II being Capcom’s best-selling consumer game of all-time as of 2008.

Street Fighter II follows several of the conventions and rules already established by its original 1987 predecessor. The player engages opponents in one-on-one close quarter combat in a series of best-two-out-of-three matches. The objective of each round is to deplete the opponent’s vitality before the timer runs out. If both opponents knock each other out at the same time or the timer runs out with both fighters having an equal amount of vitality left, a “double KO” or “draw game” is declared and additional rounds will be played until sudden death. In the first Street Fighter II, a match could last up to ten rounds if there was no clear winner; this was reduced to four rounds in Champion Edition and onward. If there is no clear winner by the end of the final round, then either the computer-controlled opponent will win by default in a single-player match or both fighters will lose in a 2-player match.

After every third match in the single player mode, the player will participate in a “bonus game” for additional points. The bonus games includes (in order) a car-breaking event; a barrel breaking bonus game where the barrels are dropped off from a conveyor belt above the player; and a drum-breaking bonus game where drums are flammable and piled over each other. The bonus games were removed from the arcade version of Super Street Fighter II Turbo.

Like in the original, the game’s controls uses a configuration of an eight-directional joystick and six attack buttons. The player uses the joystick to jump, crouch and move the character towards or away from the opponent, as well as to guard the character from an opponent’s attacks. There are three punch buttons and three kick buttons of differing strength and speed (Light, Medium and Heavy). The player can perform a variety of basic moves in any position, including grabbing/throwing attacks, which were not featured in the original Street Fighter. Like in the original, the player can perform special moves by inputting a combination of directional and button-based commands.

Street Fighter II differs from the original due to the selection of multiple playable characters, each with their distinct fighting styles and special moves. Additionally, the player can also “cancel” during animation by performing another move, allowing for a combination of several basic and special moves. Both of these features would be expanded upon in subsequent installments.

constellations_other.description: Alice Babidge's costume design for True History of the Kelly Gang sees the iconic foursome and their accomplices in dresses, a gender-expansive stance that connects to other rebellious outlooks on the world.

links.description: The fight sequences in Scott Pilgrim vs. the World reference a number of videogames, most notably including classic arcade franchise Street Fighter – Scott uses a Shoryuken attack during his battle with Matthew Patel.

links.description: The 1 vs 1 battle structure in Street Fighter II is borrowed by NZ arts collective FAFSWAG in their interactive documentary fafswagvogue. Viewers choose a dancer to vogue in a one-on-one battle, and a venue, just like in Street Fighter.

constellations_other.name: Pink, Pose, punk, Pilgrim
constellations_other.description: Alice Babidge's costume design for True History of the Kelly Gang sees the iconic foursome and their accomplices in dresses, a gender-expansive stance that connects to other rebellious outlooks on the world.

end.title: Pose
end.brief_description: A dance musical that explores the juxtaposition of several segments of 1980s life and society in New York: the ball culture world, the rise of the luxury Trump-era universe and the downtown social and literary scene.

constellations_other.name: Marlene Dietrich: queering gender onscreen
constellations_other.description: Marlene Dietrich is an icon of queer style – from her proud bisexuality to her scandalous decision to wear a tuxedo on the red carpet. This constellation explores androgyny, gender non-conformity and drag on screen in the century since Dietrich's performance in Morocco (1930).

constellations_other.name: Pink, Pose, punk, Pilgrim
constellations_other.description: Alice Babidge's costume design for True History of the Kelly Gang sees the iconic foursome and their accomplices in dresses, a gender-expansive stance that connects to other rebellious outlooks on the world.

links.description: The vogue battling depicted in Pose has been adopted by queer communities around the world, including FAFSWAG, a collective of queer Maori and Pasifika activists in New Zealand. Their practice crosses theatre, film, community events, and interactive digital media, such as their documentary FAFSWAGVOGUE.COM

start.title: Pose
start.brief_description: A dance musical that explores the juxtaposition of several segments of 1980s life and society in New York: the ball culture world, the rise of the luxury Trump-era universe and the downtown social and literary scene.

end.title: Gentleman Jack
end.brief_description: Halifax, West Yorkshire, England, 1832. Anne Lister attempts to revitalize her inherited home, Shibden Hall. Most notably for the time period, a part of her plan is to help the fate of her own family - by taking a wife.

constellations_other.name: Pink, Pose, punk, Pilgrim
constellations_other.description: Alice Babidge's costume design for True History of the Kelly Gang sees the iconic foursome and their accomplices in dresses, a gender-expansive stance that connects to other rebellious outlooks on the world.

links.description: Both series deal with historical pioneers of gender fluidity; Gentleman Jack in 1830s York, Pose in the New York ballroom culture of the late 1980s and early 1990s.

start.title: Gentleman Jack
start.brief_description: Halifax, West Yorkshire, England, 1832. Anne Lister attempts to revitalize her inherited home, Shibden Hall. Most notably for the time period, a part of her plan is to help the fate of her own family - by taking a wife.

end.title: True History of the Kelly Gang
end.creator_credit: Alice Babidge, Brad Feinstein, Hal Vogel and Liz Watts
end.brief_description: True History of the Kelly Gang is a 2019 British-Australian biographical western film based on the exploits of Australia’s famous outlaw, Ned Kelly. It’s directed by Justin Kurzel, from a screenplay by Shaun Grant, based upon the 2000 novel of the same name by Peter Carey.

constellations_primary.name: The Australian industry
constellations_primary.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

constellations_primary.name: Alice Babidge and True History of the Kelly Gang
constellations_primary.description: An acclaimed set, costume, and production designer in the world of theatre, Alice Babidge has most recently been working in film including Justin Kurzel features Snowtown and True History Of The Kelly Gang.

constellations_other.name: Pink, Pose, punk, Pilgrim
constellations_other.description: Alice Babidge's costume design for True History of the Kelly Gang sees the iconic foursome and their accomplices in dresses, a gender-expansive stance that connects to other rebellious outlooks on the world.

constellations_other.name: Inspired design and costume sketches
constellations_other.description: Costume designers Edie Kurzer and Alice Babidge have worked on some of the most acclaimed Australian and international films and TV, joining the ranks of fellow Australians creatives.

links.description: Through Alice Babidge’s costumes, a softer genderfluidity and queering of a hypermasculine Australian icon – Ned Kelly – is presented. Gentleman Jack is based on Anne Lister, a 19th-century landowner whose masculine appearance and rejection of gender roles caused a ruckus.

start.title: Costume dresses from the True History of the Kelly Gang
start.brief_description: Crafted from used vintage fabrics and sourced from markets, the individualised dresses in True History of the Kelly Gang are likened to warpaint to scare the enemy by the film’s characters, but they also speak to their inner selves.

links.description: The actors playing the Kelly Gang formed a punk band, wrote an album and performed live before filming started. Similarly the cast of the band Sex Bob-omb in Scott Pilgrim vs. the World rehearsed songs for weeks before filming.
